text: Everyone loves the word storytelling in business. It's a huge buzzword. They love to think of themselves as storytellers, but when they come to me, they don't really want to be storytellers. Because to be a storyteller means you have to separate yourself from the herd, and in their mind, that risks them getting picked off, right? Getting picked off by some predator. But the alternative is you're in the herd, which means you're forgettable.
speaker: Matthew Dicks
context: Lenny asks Matthew about the risks of being too safe and generic in business communication. Matthew explains the paradox many business professionals face with storytelling - while everyone claims to want to be a storyteller, most are actually afraid to stand out from their competitors. He describes the tension between playing it safe (staying in the herd) versus taking the risk of being memorable through authentic storytelling.
text_ko: 비즈니스에서 '스토리텔링 (storytelling)'이라는 말을 다들 좋아해요. 큰 버즈워드 (buzzword)이기도 하고요. 스스로를 스토리텔러라고 생각하는 걸 좋아하지만, 막상 제게 찾아오는 사람들은 진짜 스토리텔러가 되고 싶어하지 않아요. 스토리텔러가 된다는 건 무리에서 자신을 분리해야 한다는 뜻이라, 그럼 표적이 될 위험이 있다고 생각하거든요 — 어떤 포식자한테 잡아먹히는 것처럼요. 그런데 반대로 무리 속에 남아 있으면 눈에 띄지 않아서 금방 잊혀지게 돼요.
text_zh: 现在做生意的人都特别爱说"讲故事"这个词，简直是个超级热门词汇(buzzword)。他们都喜欢把自己当成讲故事的人，但真找到我的时候，其实他们根本不想当什么讲故事的人。因为要想讲好故事，你就得从人群中脱颖而出，但在他们心里，这样做风险太大，容易被人盯上，对吧？就像被捕食者盯上一样。但反过来说，如果你就混在人群里，那你就是个可有可无、没人记得住的角色。
text_es: A todo el mundo le encanta la palabra storytelling en los negocios. Es un término súper de moda. Les gusta pensar que son storytellers, pero cuando vienen a verme, en realidad no quieren serlo. Porque ser un storyteller significa que tienes que separarte del rebaño, y en su mente, eso los pone en riesgo de que los cacen, ¿no? Que los agarre algún depredador. Pero la alternativa es quedarte en el rebaño, lo cual significa que eres olvidable.

text: Every story essentially about a singular moment. I call it five seconds. It can be one second honestly. It's a moment of either transformation, meaning I'm telling you a story about how I once used to be one kind of person and now I'm a new kind of person. Or more common is realization. Which is I used to think something and then some stuff happened and now I think a new thing.
speaker: Matthew Dicks
context: Lenny asks Matthew about his concept that all good stories center around one five-second moment. Matthew explains that every compelling story is built around a singular moment of either transformation (becoming a different type of person) or realization (changing what you think about something). This moment is what the entire story should build toward, with 98% of the story serving as context to bring that crucial moment into sharp focus for the audience.
text_ko: 결국 모든 이야기는 한 순간에 관한 거예요. 저는 그걸 '5초'라고 부르는데요. 솔직히 말하면 1초일 수도 있어요. 그 순간은 두 가지예요. 하나는 변화의 순간이에요 — 예전에는 이런 사람이었는데 지금은 다른 사람이 됐다는 이야기죠. 더 흔한 건 깨달음이에요. 예전에는 이렇게 생각했는데 어떤 일이 일어나서 지금은 다르게 생각하게 됐다는 경우예요.
text_zh: 其实每个故事的核心就是那关键的一瞬间，我叫它"五秒钟时刻"，说实话有时候一秒钟就够了。这个时刻要么是转变——就是我要跟你讲我以前是什么样的人，现在变成了什么样的人。要么更常见的是顿悟——就是我以前是这么想的，然后发生了一些事，现在我的想法完全不一样了。
text_es: Toda historia básicamente trata de un momento único. Yo le digo los cinco segundos. Puede ser un segundo, la verdad. Es un momento de transformación, o sea, te estoy contando una historia de cómo antes era un tipo de persona y ahora soy otra. O lo más común es la realización. Que es: antes pensaba algo, luego pasaron cosas, y ahora pienso algo diferente.

text: The dinner test is the idea that when you're telling a story in a formal way, if you're performing on a stage or delivering a keynote or even delivering a pitch to entrepreneurs or a sales pitch, essentially the story that you're telling should be very closely related to the story you would tell someone if you were having dinner.
speaker: Matthew Dicks
context: Lenny asks Matthew about his checklist for what makes a good story. Matthew explains the 'dinner test' - one of his key criteria for effective storytelling. The dinner test means that formal presentations should sound like slightly elevated versions of natural conversation, avoiding artificial performance elements like unattributed dialogue or dramatic sound effects that would seem bizarre in normal conversation.
text_ko: 디너 테스트(dinner test)는 공식적인 자리에서 스토리를 전할 때—무대에서 발표를 하거나 기조연설(keynote)을 하거나 창업가들에게 피치(pitch)를 하거나 영업 피치(sales pitch)를 할 때조차—사실상 그 이야기는 누군가와 저녁 식사하면서 편하게 나눌 이야기와 거의 같아야 한다는 생각이에요.
text_zh: 晚餐测试(dinner test)这个概念是说，当你正式讲故事的时候，不管是在台上演讲、做主题发言(keynote)，还是向创业者路演(pitch)或者做销售展示，你讲的故事本质上应该和你跟朋友吃饭聊天时讲的故事差不多。
text_es: La prueba de la cena es la idea de que cuando estás contando una historia de manera formal, ya sea que estés presentando en un escenario o dando una charla magistral (keynote) o incluso haciendo un pitch a emprendedores o una presentación de ventas, básicamente la historia que estás contando debería ser muy parecida a la historia que le contarías a alguien si estuvieras cenando con esa persona.

text: Stakes are essentially what your audience should be worried about, what they should be wanting for you, what they should be concerned about, what they should be wondering about. If your audience isn't wondering what you're about to say, they're no longer listening to you. And you have to internalize that in a deep and fundamental way.
speaker: Matthew Dicks
context: Lenny asks Matthew to explain what stakes are and why they're important in storytelling. Matthew explains that stakes are what keep audiences engaged by giving them something to worry about or wonder about. He emphasizes that business professionals often mistakenly assume people want to hear what they have to say, when in reality, speakers must constantly work to maintain audience attention through creating uncertainty and concern about what happens next.
vocabulary_highlights: internalize that in a deep and fundamental way
text_ko: 여기서 '중요 쟁점(stakes)'은 본질적으로 청중(audience)이 걱정해야 할 것, 당신에게 바라는 것, 신경 써야 할 것, 궁금해해야 할 것을 말해요. 청중이 다음에 당신이 뭘 말할지 궁금해하지 않으면, 그들은 더 이상 당신의 말을 듣고 있는 게 아니에요. 이걸 깊고 근본적으로 내 것으로 만들어야 해요.
text_zh: 关键点(stakes)其实就是你要让听众担心的事情，让他们为你着急，让他们关注，让他们好奇。如果听众对你接下来要说什么一点都不好奇，那他们根本就不会认真听你讲。这个道理你得真正理解透，从骨子里明白这一点。
text_es: Las consecuencias son básicamente lo que tu audiencia debería preocuparles, lo que deberían estar deseando para ti, lo que debería inquietarles, sobre lo que deberían estar preguntándose. Si tu audiencia no se está preguntando qué vas a decir después, ya no te están escuchando. Y tienes que interiorizar eso de manera profunda y fundamental.

text: If you don't tell stories as part of your business, whether you're looking for investment, or speaking to your people, or speaking to customers, or clients, anything, if you're not telling stories, the good news is, you're just like everybody else. The bad news is, you're mediocre just like everybody else. You're in a lane that everyone else is in, which means that you're going to be forgettable.
speaker: Matthew Dicks
context: Lenny asks Matthew about the benefits of learning storytelling skills versus the problems people face if they don't develop these abilities. Matthew explains the cost of not using storytelling in business - while it feels safe to communicate the same way as everyone else, this approach makes you completely forgettable. He contrasts this with the alternative of using stories to stand out and be memorable, even though it requires more courage.
text_ko: 사업에서 스토리텔링(storytelling)을 하지 않으면, 투자를 구하든 직원들에게 말하든 고객이나 클라이언트와 이야기하든—어떤 상황에서건 이야기를 하지 않는다면 좋은 소식은 다른 사람들과 다를 바 없다는 거예요. 나쁜 소식은 그만큼 평범하다는 뜻이에요. 결국 모두가 있는 같은 영역에 서 있게 돼서 기억에 남지 않게 돼요.
text_zh: 如果你做生意不会讲故事，不管是找投资、跟员工说话、还是面对客户，什么场合都不讲故事的话，好消息是你跟大家都一样；坏消息是你跟大家一样平庸。你走的路跟所有人都一样，这就意味着你会被人忘记。
text_es: Si no usas historias en tu negocio, ya sea que busques inversión, que hables con tu equipo, con clientes, lo que sea, si no cuentas historias, la buena noticia es que eres igual que todos los demás. La mala noticia es que eres del montón, igual que todos. Estás en el mismo carril que todo el mundo, lo que significa que van a olvidarse de ti.

text: I have this tool I use with corporate folks called, a personal interest inventory. It is a list of all the things that you should be saying about yourself in clever and strategic ways that I teach. Each one of them has an addressable market. So how many people could this potentially hit? And then the intensity of the connection.
speaker: Matthew Dicks
context: Lenny asks Matthew about his advice to make business stories more personal. Matthew introduces his 'personal interest inventory' concept - a strategic approach to sharing personal details that help people connect with you. He explains how different personal attributes have varying 'addressable markets' (how many people can relate) and connection intensity (how strongly people who share that trait will connect with you), helping professionals decide which personal elements to strategically include in their communication.
text_ko: 회사 분들과 함께 쓸 때 제가 사용하는 도구가 하나 있어요. ‘개인 관심 목록(personal interest inventory)’이라고 부르는데, 제가 가르치는 방식대로 자신에 대해 영리하고 전략적으로 말해야 할 것들을 모두 정리한 목록이에요. 각 항목마다 도달 가능한 시장(addressable market)이 있어서, 이게 잠재적으로 몇 명에게 닿을 수 있는지와 그 연결의 강도가 얼마나 되는지를 따져보는 거예요.
text_zh: 我有个工具专门用来跟企业高管们一起用的，叫个人兴趣清单(personal interest inventory)。就是把你应该怎么巧妙地、有策略地介绍自己的那些点都列出来，我会教你怎么说。每一个点都有它的目标受众(addressable market)。你想想看，这能影响到多少人？还有就是这种连接的强度有多深。
text_es: Tengo una herramienta que uso con la gente de las empresas que se llama inventario de intereses personales (personal interest inventory). Es una lista de todas las cosas que deberías estar diciendo de ti mismo de manera inteligente y estratégica, eso es lo que enseño. Cada una de esas cosas tiene un mercado al que puedes dirigirte. Entonces, ¿a cuánta gente podría llegar esto potencialmente? Y después está la intensidad de esa conexión.
